comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Grooooaaaannn! :D Here's the full text: In the Year 1003 This Tower was erected By Reginald the Dane In 1171 it was held as a Fortress by Strongbow Earl of Pembroke In 1463 by Statute 3rd Edward 4th a Mint was established here In 1819 it was Reedified in its original Form & appropriated to The Police Establishment by the corporate Body of The City of Waterford Rt. Hon. Sir John Newport Bt. M.P. Mayor Henry Alcock Esqr William Weekes Esqr Sheriffs mogey was almost spot on...

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
I wonder if Edward I Waterford coinage was also minted at Reginald's Tower?

Certainly, Edward IV had his Waterford coins minted there but the scale of his coinage was far less than that of Edward I.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] This website seems good on Edward I coinage and quantities minted at Waterford, though Reginald's Tower is not mentioned.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] Thank you. That's John Stafford-Langdon's excellent website on Irish coinage. Unfortunately, he does not state the exact location for Edward I Waterford mint. Maybe the location of Edward I Waterford mint is unknown?

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: This is a brief history of Reginalds Tower on the Waterford City Councils website, www.waterfordcity.ie/city/walls/reginalds-tower.htm Interesting piece on a 12th century coin balance in the Reginalds Tower exhibition, www.askaboutireland.ie/reading-room/arts-literature/the-v...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Brilliant, thanks - this piece on the coin balance and the practice of coin clipping is excellent. And [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] it appears that Ask About Ireland, always very reliable in my experience, are saying that Edward I's mint was probably in Reginald's Tower...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
OMG! This was back in the days of the Ford "You can have any colour as long as it's black" Model T and many many years before the Transit was ever thought of! 

Mind you having said all of that....is there any material on the Library on "The Violet Bus Service" which is named after "The Violet" public house in Blackrock, Co. Louth and which has run for a very long time between Dundalk and Blackrock.

My family used to travel from Belfast to Blackrock for their annual holidays!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] Nothing I could find on a quick search of our catalogue, but I'm sure such a long standing bus service would be covered in individual local history/transport, etc. journal articles... Found this from very cursory Google search.
